channel.title: Blogpost on Resul Umit
channel.description: Recent content in Blogpost on Resul Umit

item.title: Parliamentary communication allowances do not increase electoral turnout or affect incumbents’ vote share.
item.description: A blogpost that I wrote for LSE British Politics and Policy, summarising the findings of my journal article, Parliamentary Communication Allowances: Good for Nothing?.

item.title: What determines how much an MP spends on communicating with their constituents?
item.description: A blogpost—that Katrin Auel and I wrote for LSE British Politics and Policy—summarising the findings of our journal article, Explaining MPs’ communication to their constituents.

item.title: Most British MPs used to avoid tweeting about the EU, leaving Eurosceptics to fill the gap.
item.description: A blogpost—that I wrote for LSE Brexit—summarising the findings of my journal article, Strategic communication of EU affairs.

item.title: Austria’s presidential race is heading for a third round—here are the lessons from the first two.
item.description: A blogpost—that Mario Gavenda I wrote for LSE EUROPP—summarising the findings of our journal article, the 2016 Austrian presidential election.

item.title: MPs in safe seats are more likely to become ministers.
item.description: A blogpost—that I wrote for the Democratic Audit UK—about my co-autered article with Elad Klein, Ministerial selection in the UK.
